headline.main: May 22-28: Trail Blazers; Florida and Mississippi Challenge Cigarette Manufacturers

docs.lead_paragraph: In decades of litigation with smokers suffering from lung cancer and other diseases, tobacco companies have never lost a product-liability case. But the industry came under attack on two new fronts last week, as Florida passed a law specifically designed to make it much more difficult for cigarette manufacturers to maintain that perfect record and Mississippi became the first state to sue them for health damages on behalf of its taxpayers. Florida's action was potentially the more far-reaching of the two, and the Tobacco Institute responded angrily, calling the law "a travesty." By forbidding cigarette makers from arguing in court that consumers know the risks when they begin to smoke, the group charged, the law cheats "legitimate products out of the right to evidentiary protection and defenses."
